description.narrative:
Partner Name: Reproductive and Child Health Alliance (RACHA) The Reproductive and Child Health Alliance (RACHA) is an USAID-funded project that started in 1996 and is currently in the process of becoming a registered local NGO. The transition to local NGO status is expected to be completed by the end of 2002. RACHA#s core objectives are to increase the supply of, demand for and access to reproductive child health (RCH) services.
RACHA works through the Ministry of Health, following MoH policy, gaining MoH approval of allRACHA-supported activities, and engaging MoH staff directly in the implementation of RCH activities sponsored by RACHA. RACHA has years of experience working with all levels of the MoH, from national to health centre and to communities via Village Health Support Group (VHSG), in trying to build functional linkages between levels in a complementary and supportive fashion to help the system work more effectively and produce greater impact. Ultimately, the goal is to improve RCH services and health conditions at the community level; therefore, RACHA is a predominantly rural-focused organization.
RACHA has recently been granted by USAID another five-year(2014-2019) Empowering Communities for Health (ECH) Project (USAID-Cambodia-442-13-00004-RFA). The project will cover a total of 36Operational Districts within nine provinces comprising more than 7,000 villages. In 2014-2015, RACHA initially works in cluster 1 composed of two provinces of Siem Reap and Banteay Meanchey. The project will be gradually scaled up to clusters 2 and 3 in the following year.
Project Title: Empowering women through enhanced leadership skills and created their own economic opprtunity.
The specific objectives for the SfC project are to build the grassroots# voice through enhancing women#s community political leadership actions, and to support the maturity of existing SfC groups to the point that they will be able to function independently and sustainably. The overall outcomes for the SfC project are to ensure vulnerable small-scale farmers (VSFs) possess financial security against shocks, enhance solidarity and the collective voices community, and enable an environment of saving-led and self-reliant approaches.These objectives and outcomes aimed to beachieved through key activities. These activities include providing technical assistance to strengthen leadership, decision making and advocacy skills among active female members of functioning saving groups, and providingtechnical support to strengthenthe capacity of existing saving groups to mature and be independent.

participating-org.narrative:
The Reproductive and Child Health Alliance (RACHA) is an USAID-funded project that started in 1996 and is currently in the process of becoming a registered local NGO. The transition to local NGO status is expected to be completed by the end of 2002. RACHA#s core objectives are to increase the supply of, demand for and access to reproductive child health (RCH) services.

RACHA has years of experience working with all levels of the MoH, from national to health centre and to communities via Village Health Support Group (VHSG), in trying to buildfunctional linkages between levels in a complementary and supportive fashion to help the system work more effectively and produce greater impact. Ultimately, the goal is to improve RCH services and health conditions at the community level; therefore, RACHAis a predominantly rural-focused organization.
RACHA has recently been granted by USAID another five-year (2014-2019) Empowering Communities for Health (ECH) Project (USAID-Cambodia-442-13-00004-RFA). sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: Women and Men able to: # of people (M/F) living in poverty and injustice use their enhanced knowledge and skills to increase their productivity and/or income, or to strengthen their bargaining position, ensuring equal benefit to men and women.
